definition.value: Used to broadly characterize a food product based on the extent of heat applied. Heat treatment affects the flavor and textural characteristics of a food and thus consumer preparation time. Heat treatment causes chemical changes and/or reduction of enzyme and of microbial activity and thus affects food safety and shelflife. Specifics of preparation are covered by *G. COOKING METHOD* and *H. TREATMENT APPLIED*. [FDA CFSAN 1995]

LanguaL curation note: Used when heat was applied to a food product for a time sufficient to fully change its flavor and textural characteristics and to cause significant chemical changes and/or destruction of enzyme and microbial activity. The product can be consumed without further cooking.

LanguaL curation note: Used when heat was applied to a food product for a time sufficient to partially change its flavor and textural characteristics and to cause some chemical changes and/or some reduction in enzyme and microbial activity. The product can be readied for consumption in a shortened cooking time. Products labeled 'quick cooking' are often partially heat treated. Some products are consumed partially heat-treated, e.g., pasteurized milk, blanched broccoli, or rare beef.

label.value: heat-treated, multiple components, different degrees of treatment

definition.value: LanguaL curation note: Used for foods containing several different components, each of which may have had a different *EXTENT OF HEAT TREATMENT*. An example would be a cheeseburger with a fully cooked bun and meat but a partially cooked slice of cheese and possibly raw tomato and lettuce.
Cooked at moderate to high levels of heat in which no liquid is added and only small amounts of fat may be added to prevent sticking.
LanguaL
Cooked without moisture, covered or uncovered, in an oven.
Cooked without moisture under or over intense direct heat.
Cooked without moisture over direct heat from a charcoal fire.
Cooking on a flat surface at medium heat with only a sufficient amount of fat used to prevent sticking.
Cooking by agitating the food over a dry, high heat source, resulting in exploding.
Cooking with direct heat until the surface of the food is browned, usually associated with bread or sandwiches.
Cooking in a microwave oven.
Cooking in varying amounts of water, water-based liquid or steam.
LanguaL curation note: If the food absorbs a significant amount of water, also used *REHYDRATED* or *WATER ADDED*.

label.value: cooking in water or water-based liquid

definition.value: A process of cooking by moist heat which is effected by hot water or water-based liquid in a container.
A cooking in water or water-based liquid process in which the liquid is boiling.
Water at standard atmospheric pressure (in other words, at sea level) will boil at a temperature of 100 degrees C (212 degrees F).
Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F.; water that is not absorbed into the food product is discarded after cooking.

label.value: boiling in large amount of liquid

definition.value: Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F. Liquid to solid ratio is greater than 2:1.

label.value: boiling in small amount of liquid

definition.value: Cooked in boiling water at 212 degrees F. The water incorporates itself into the product being cooked or is not discarded when cooking is complete.
Browned initially in fat and then tightly covered and cooked over low heat in a small amount of water.
Cooking in a moderate amount of liquid at just below the boiling point.
Cooked in a pressure cooker.
Cooked suspended above boiling water.

label.value: cooking with added fat or oil

definition.value: Cooked by adding fat or oil to those foods that do not contain fat or oil that would render during the cooking process.

label.value: cooking in small amount of fat or oil

definition.value: Cooked with sufficient fat or oil to coat and moisten the food being prepared, but not cooked in enough fat or oil to immerse the food.
Use *griddle cooking* when only enough fat or oil is used to prevent sticking.
Cooking in a very small amount of very hot fat, turning and browning the food on all sides.
Cooked by frying foods quickly over high heat, stirring constantly. Only enough cooking oil is used to coat the bottom of the pan.
Cooked in hot fat or oil deep enough to immerse the food entirely.

label.value: cooking with inherent fat or oil

definition.value: Cooked in fat or oil rendered from the food being prepared.

label.value: heating container by immersion in water or steam

definition.value: LanguaL curation note: Used when the food is cooked in a closed container such as a pouch immersed in hot water or steam.
A food cooking method in which heat is transferred to the outside of a container.
Heating a container that is placed in another container filled with boiling water.
Heating a container that is placed in another container filled with water kept near the boiling point.
A chinese cooking technique similar to sauteing in which thick slices or chunks of floured or battered ingredients are slow seared over moderate to low heat.
Extracting flavor and other components from food sources by immersion in water, usually at near-boiling temperature.
A process to bring an already fully cooked product to serving temperature.
LanguaL curation note: Do not use for a process that completes the cooking of a partially cooked food.

label.value: food reheating in pan or cooking utensil

definition.value: A Chinese cooking technique to prepare delicate food such as bird nests, shark fins, etc. The food is covered with water and put in a covered ceramic jar and the jar is then steamed for several hours.
This technique ensures there is no loss of liquid or moisture (its essences) from the food being cooked, hence it is often used with expensive ingredients like Chinese herbal medicines. [Wikipedia]
Rotisserie is a style of roasting where meat is skewered on a spit and revolves over a flame or other heat source.
The rotation cooks the meat evenly in its own juices and allows easy access for continuous basting if desired. [Wikipedia]

Searing is a technique used in grilling, roasting, braising, sautéing, etc. that cooks the surface of the food at high temperature so that a brownish crust forms by Maillard reaction and denaturation of proteins.

A similar technique, browning, is typically used to sear or brown all sides of a particular piece of meat, fish, poultry, etc. before finishing it in the oven. To obtain the desired brown crust, the meat surface must exceed 300 °F (150 °C), so searing requires the meat surface be free of water, which boils at around 212 °F (100 °C).
LanguaL curation note: Use when a pie crust or other pastry is baked without the filling.
LanguaL curation note: Use when e.g. meat and cooking oil are brought to high temperatures while pressure is held high enough that the water within is prevented from boiling off.

label.value: flavoring or spice extract or concentrate
